intro: Papaver commutatum subsp. euxinum, commonly known as the Crimean poppy, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is characterized by its striking, bright red or orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy. Its flowers consist of a single, showy pistil surrounded by several stamens, typical of the Papaveraceae family. This species is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also found in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky soils.
